metadata.title: Electrospun Nanomaterials for Supercapacitor Electrodes: Designed Architectures and Electrochemical Performance

sections.text:
R ev iew
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (1 of 43) 1601301wileyonlinelibrary.com
Electrospun Nanomaterials for Supercapacitor Electrodes: Designed Architectures and Electrochemical Performance
Xiaofeng Lu,* Ce Wang, Frédéric Favier, and Nicola Pinna*
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201601301

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the fast consumption of fossil fuels and increasing environmental issues, there is an urgent need for the development of efficient, sustainable and renewable energy sources from
Electrospinning is the most facile and highly versatile approach to produce 1D polymeric, inorganic, and hybrid nanomaterials with a small diameter, controllable dimensions, and designed architectures. In particular, with large surface area, high porosity, low density, good directionality, and tunable composition, electrospun nanofibers and mats are regarded as ideal candidates for various kinds of electrochemical energy storage devices such as supercapacitors (SCs). In this review, the recent progress in electrospun electrode materials for SCs is presented, covering the architecture design and their electrochemical performance. After a brief introduction about SCs, the basic principles of the electrospinning technique are discussed. Following, attention is paid to the discussion of various electrospun nanofibers and mats including 1D carbons, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitrides, conducting polymers and composite nanomaterials with various types of architectures as electrodes for SCs. The relationship between the composition, architecture, and the electrochemical performance is discussed in detail. Finally, some challenges and perspectives of future research of the electrospun nanofibers and mats for high performance SCs are highlighted. It is anticipated that this review would provide the researchers some inspiration for constructing new types of energy storage devices.

solar energy, hydropower, bioenergy, wind power, etc. Since most of the above available energy sources are intermittent in nature, electrochemical energy storage systems including fuel cells, batteries and electrochemical capacitors are starting to have more and more impact in our lives.[1,2] Specifically, electrochemical capacitors or supercapacitors (SCs) are energy storage devices which store and release electric energy with extremely fast charge/ discharge rates, and display high power densities, superb cyclic lifetimes, low maintenance cost, and safe operation.[3–8] Such promising performances enable SCs to be potentially applicable in vehicles, portable electronics, memory backup systems, and other electronic industries.
On the basis of charge storage mechanism, SCs can be classified into electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors.[3] EDLC stores the electric charges on the surface of the electrode and opposite charged ions on the electrolyte side through reversible ion adsorption/desorption process. This elec-
trostatic charge storage mechanism not only guarantees fast energy uptake and delivery, but also avoids the swelling of the electrode materials, providing the EDLCs unique power performance and very long cyclic lifetime. With the advantage of high specific surface area, good conductivity, electrochemical stability in solutions with a wide range of pH values, and ease of preparation protocols, graphitic carbons have become the most promising candidates for EDLC applications.[9] In the past few decades, diverse types of carbonaceous materials such as activated carbon (AC), carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers (CNFs), graphene, carbon onions, and carbon nanohorns, etc. have been extensively studied as EDLC electrodes.[10–14] For example, ACs with large BET surface area (500–3000 m2 g−1) are already used in commercialized EDLC.[10] Electrolyte is also a key factor to determine the capacitance performance of EDLCs. It is noted that the double layer capacitance of the carbonaceous materials in organic electrolytes is much lower than that in aqueous electrolytes because of the high resistance of the organic electrolytes.[6] However, the operating voltage is much lower (only about 1 V) in aqueous electrolyte due to the limitation of the electrochemical water decomposition, whereas it can be increased to more than 2.0 V in organic electrolyte[15] and even far beyond 3.0 V in ionic liquid electrolyte.[16]
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1601301

In comparison to EDLCs, pseudocapacitors store charge through reversible redox reaction between electrode materials and electrolytes, involving electrosorption and reduction-oxidation reaction processes. As the electrochemical processes can occur not only on the surface but also in the bulk of the electrode materials, more charges can be stored in pseudocapacitors compared to EDLCs. Consequently, the specific capacitance and energy density of pseudocapacitors are higher than those of EDLCs. Generally, the capacitance of pseudocapacitors can reach up to several hundreds of Farad per gram of active material. The measurement for the electrochemical response can be designed as either a half cell or a full cell. The half cell usually consists of three electrodes (working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode), while the full cell are composed of two electrodes (positive and negative electrode). The full cell SC provides a realistic measure of the charge–discharge behavior that occurs in a commercial device. However, the half cell is also required as it can afford the potential information of the working electrode. Generally, the specific capacitance that is measured in a half cell is a little higher than that in a full cell. In previous studies, electroactive transition metal oxides such as RuO2, MnO2, Fe3O4, Co3O4, NiO and electronically conducting polymers such as polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), polythiophene (PTh), and their derivatives are typical examples of pseudocapacitive electrode materials.[17–26] RuO2 is one of the most efficient electrode material for pseudocapacitor due to its good conductivity, distinct multiple reversible redox states accessible within a potential window of 1.2 V. In an acidic solution, the pseudocapacitor behavior mainly includes a reversible electron transfer and the electroadsorption of protons. By using amorphous hydrated RuO2 powders as pesudocapacitor electrode, a specific capacitance higher than 600 F g−1 has been achieved.[27] Recently, specific capacitance as high as 1038 F g−1 has also been reported for the hydrated RuO2 nanosheets.[28] Although RuO2 electrodes show high capacitance, the high cost and small voltage window limit their wide applications in electronic devices. Among low-cost transition metal oxides, MnO2 is the most promising electrode for pseudocapacitors for its high theoretical specific capacitance, easy preparation, and environmentally friendliness.[18,19] It has been reported that the specific capacitance of MnO2 thin film electrode, exhibiting a very low mass loading, can reach 1380 F g−1. However, the limited surface capacitance restricts its practical applications.[29] Conducting polymers are another type of pseudo-capacitive materials for SCs applications. Owing to their high electrical conductivity and reversible electrochemical doping-dedoping characteristics, they exhibit high specific capacitance and power density.[24–26] However, bulk conducting polymers display a remarkably low stability during cycling, limiting their widely practical applications. Therefore, current efforts are focused on hybrid systems based on conducting polymers.
To improve the performance of SCs, a large variety of nanomaterials with various structures including zero, one, two and 3D nanostructures have been fabricated in recent years. Among those, 1D nanostructured materials have attracted more and more attention for their advantages of large specific surface area, efficient electron transport along one direction, and ease for construction of nanodevices.[30,31] In the past few decades, many synthetic strategies including template-directed synthesis,

vapor-phase approach, solution-phase method, melt-blown protocols, electrospinning technique, self-assembly method, and electrodeposition have been developed to prepare various kinds of 1D nanostructured nanomaterials.[32–34] Among them, electrospinning technique is the most facile and highly versatile approach to produce 1D polymeric, inorganic and hybrid nanomaterials with a small diameter, controllable dimensions, and designed architectures.[35–38] In contrast to other techniques to fabricate 1D nanomaterials, electrospinning allows for the direct fabrication of self-supported membranes. Moreover, high porosity, low density, controllable directionality, and ease of incorporation of multiple components into a single nanofiber are also achievable by electrospinning. Therefore, electrospun nanofibers present suitable properties for application in the field of SCs.
Much work has been done on the fabrication of electrospun nanofibers, nanotubes, coaxial nanocables, and hierarchical nanomaterials for energy storage devices, such as lithium batteries, sodium batteries, and SCs, and there are also some excellent reviews devoted to this subject.[39–46] However, no comprehensive review focused on the application of electrospun nanomaterials for SCs has been published yet. More importantly, growing number of publications on electrospun nanomaterials for SCs have appeared in the last few years. Therefore, this review is intended to present the recent research activities on electrospun nanomaterials for SC applications. Electrospun materials as electrodes for SCs are classified in material classes, including carbons, metal oxides, sulfides, nitrides, conducting polymers and organic-inorganic hybrid materials. For each material class, the nanostructures that could be obtained such as solid nanofibers, porous nanofibers, coaxial nanocables, hollow nanotubes, and hierarchical structured materials are firstly introduced. The emphasis is then directed for addressing the relationship between the composition and nanostructure of the electrospun nanomaterials, and the electrochemical properties. Finally, open challenges and other important future directions in order to bring devices based on electrospun nanofibers
to the market will be also tackled. It is anticipated that this review article does not only address the recent developments of electrospun nanomaterials for SCs, but would also stimulate some new ideas and push forward this fast developing field of research.

sections.heading: 2.1. Basic Principle of Electrospinning Technique
sections.text:
Electrospinning is a facile, low-cost and highly versatile approach to generate 1D continuous polymeric nanomaterials with diameters down to nanometer range under a high electric field.[35–38] By mixing additional components into the electrospun polymeric solution or combining with post-treatment processes, 1D nanocomposites or inorganic nanomaterials can also be fabricated. Generally, the basic laboratory electrospinning equipment consists of three major parts: a high-voltage power supply, a spinneret and a grounded collector (Figure 1). The high-voltage power supply provides a high voltage from several to several tens of kilovolts which is applied between the spinneret and the conductive collector. Under a high electric field, the pendent drop of the polymer solution or melt is electrified and experienced the electrostatic forces, forming a conical shaped droplet, known as the Taylor cone, at the tip of the spinneret.[47,48] Once the strength of the electric field reaches a critical value, which make the electrostatic force overcome the surface tension, a liquid jet of the polymer solution or melt from the tip of Taylor cone will eject and elongate, moving to the electrode of the counter collector. The charged jet then undergoes an unstable and whipping process, leading to the evaporation of the solvent or the solidification of the melt and the formation of continuous solid nanofibers on the counter collector. The spinneret is usually a syringe with a needle, with an inner diameter smaller than 1 mm, serving as one of the electrodes of the electrospinning setup. To force the polymer

© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1601301 (4 of 43) wileyonlinelibrary.com
solution to be fed through the spinneret, a syringe pump is needed to provide a constant and controlled rate. Alternatively, the polymer could be confined in a glass tube with one end of small diameter or a syringe without the push rod, then the glass tube or syringe is tilted to make the polymer solution flowing due to the gravity. Electrospinning devices without a spinneret can also be fabricated, in this case the technique is called needleless electrospinning.[49] For example, Yarin and Zussman introduced a magnetic field providing by a permanent magnet or a coil to the electrospinning process, which was subject to a two-layer system containing a polymer solution and a ferromagnetic suspension. As a result, magnetic suspension perturbed the free surface of the polymer layer. When an electric field is applied to the electrospun system, the perturbations of the free surface become a large number of sites of jetting. In the following, the electrified jets undergo a stretching and bending instability, solvent evaporation process. Finally, the solid polymeric nanofibers will form on the counter electrode.[50] Compared with the normal electrospinning setup with a spinneret, the needleless electrospinning provides a simple and original approach to produce polymeric nanofibers in a high production rate.

sections.heading: 2.2. Architecture Design of Electrospun Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Tunable electrospinning parameters such as viscosity of polymer solution, types of solvent, applied voltage, the distance between the needle and the collector, feeding rate, temperature and humidity, strongly influence the morphology and nanostructure of the electrospun nanofibers.[51,52] Among these parameters, the viscosity of the polymer solution is the most important factor that determine the formation and the
diameter of the fibers. The viscosity of polymer solution can be adjusted by modifying the polymer concentration and its molecular weight. Previous studies with a large variety of polymer systems have shown that the diameter of electrospun nanofibers decreases significantly as the polymer concentration decreases.[53–55] However, when the polymer concentration decreases to a critical value, beaded nanofibers will appear in the product.[56]
To be applied in the fields of filtration, energy storage devices, and biological scaffolds, porous electrospun nanofibers are sought after due to their larger surface area compared to nonporous nanofibers. Porosity can be produced by the addition of salts, porogens, and phase separation. For instance, porous poly-l-lactide (PLLA) nanofibers have been prepared by electrospinning a polymer solution in dichloromethane.[57] The mechanism for the formation of the pores on the electrospun nanofibers is attributed to the phase separation during the solvent evaporation. As a result, a polymer-rich phase solidifies to from the matrix, whereas the solvent-rich phase forms the pores. As the solvent vapor pressure plays a key role on the formation of the pores, the use of chloroform with a lower vapor pressure instead of dichloromethane will significantly reduce the density of the pores on PLLA nanofibers. Hierarchically porous ceramic nanofibers have also been prepared through a general microemulsion electrospinning approach (Figure 2a).[58] The pores are formed where the vacancies of oil droplets after their removal from the electrospun nanofibers during the calcination process, which include not only macropores and mesopores, but also special striped pores.
In addition to porous nanofibers, electrospinning technique affords the possibility to generate nanobelts, helical nanofibers, core–sheath nanofibers, nanotubes, multichannelled tubes, side-by-side nanofibers, hierarchical nanostructures etc.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1601301
R ev iew
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (5 of 43) 1601301wileyonlinelibrary.com
(Figure 2b–h). During the electrospinning process, a skin might be formed due to the rapid solvent removal from the jet surface, subsequently reducing the solvent evaporation rate. Hollow nanotubes would be formed due to the effect of the skin, which can collapse to form nanobelts. This kind of beltlike nanostructure has been observed in many types of eletrospun polymeric nanomaterials.[59,60] Ceramic nanobelt network has also been fabricated through the electrospinning technique combined with the calcination process, which display potential applications for soft electronics (Figure 2b).[61]
Helical structured electrospun micro- and nanofibers have been of great interest in the past decade due to their potential applications in microelectromechanical system devices. The helical structured fibers have been prepared by electrospinning a two-component solution containing a conductive and a nonconductive polymer (Figure 2c).[62] The formation of the helical shape was attributed to the partial neutralization of the charged fibers and the viscoelastic contraction. A single-phase helical polymeric nanofiber has also been fabricated through the electrospinning of poly(2-acrylamido-2-methyl-1-propanesulfonic acid) in a mixed solvent of water and ethanol.[63] The mechanism of the helical structure formation was mainly attributed to the bending instability of the jet.
One of the advantages of electrospinning technique is due to the flexible design of the setup to meet the requirement of the product with some particular architecture. For example, coaxial electrospinning can be simply realized by replacing the standard needle with coaxial needle. The technique can be applied for the fabrication of core–sheath, hollow and multichannel nanofibers.[64–67] Core–sheath nanofibers can be achieved by feeding two different types of polymer solutions in the core and sheath needles, respectively, while hollow and multichannel nanofibers can be generated by removing the core materials by dissolution or calcination process (Figure 2d–f). By employing electrospun nanofibers as templates, core–sheath nanofibers can also be fabricated by coating the electrospun template through chemical vapor deposition (CVD) or atomic layer deposition (ALD), for example, hollow nanofibers can be formed when the template is removed.[68,69]
Janus nanostructures have attracted more and more attention in recent years due to different exposed surfaces on the two opposite sides. Janus nanofibers can be prepared by a side-by-side electrospinning technique. For example, sideby-side poly mer nanofibers composed of poly(vinyl chloride)/segmented polyurethane (PU) and poly(vinyl chloride)poly(vinylidiene fluoride) were first prepared by using a new designed parallel spinneret.[70] A self-crimping side-by-side poly mer nanofibers consist of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and PU were also prepared by using a silicone microfluidic device as spinneret.[71] By removing the PU moiety by an extraction process with tetrahydrofuran (THF), “U” shaped in cross-section PAN nanofibers are generated, providing an indirect evidence for the formation of side-by-side PAN/PU nanofibers. Sideby-side bicomponent ceramic TiO2/SnO2 nanofibers could also been fabricated by using a similar parallel spinneret (Figure 2g).[72] Dong and co-workers developed a modified specially designed parallel spinneret composed of two truncated stainless steel needless with separately bending at a certain angle within a plastic nozzle. By using such a spinneret,
magnetic-fluorescent bifunctional Janus nanobelts and a new type of flexible Janus nanoribbons array have been successfully fabricated.[73,74] White and co-workers prepared Janus nanofibers with tunable structures by manipulating the angle between the two parallel spinnerets.[75] Through such a strategy, many variations in the Janus structure such as the width, interfacial area, and volume of both sides can be well tuned.
Hierarchical structures can also be fabricated by electrospinning followed by additional treatment such as calcination, vapor phase deposition, ALD, hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction, controlled polymer crystallization process, etc.[76–79] Furthermore, the composition of the electrospun nanofibers can be easily tuned via the formation of the hierarchical structure. Figure 2h shows a typical V2O5-TiO2-Ta2O5 hierarchical structure synthesized by electrospinning and calcination processes. The addition of a small amount of Ta2O5 not only promotes the smoother surface of the hierarchical structure, the longer and thinner V2O5 nanorods on the fiber body, but also affects the crystallization of TiO2 and V2O5. Taking the advantages of the large surface area, optimized structure, and controllable chemical composition, hierarchical structured electrospun nanomaterials are promising electrode materials for SCs.

sections.heading: 3. Electrospun Nanomaterial Electrodes for Supercapacitors
sections.text: Electrospun nanomaterials displaying electrochemical activity and large surface area are essential for electrodes of SCs, including EDLCs and pseudocapacitors. A large variety of electrochemical active electrospun nanomaterials including carbons, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitrides, conducting polymers and nanocomposites have been developed as active electrode materials in SCs. For high capacitor performance, various architectures such as solid, porous, core–sheath, hollow and hierarchical structures have been fabricated. In this section, we will present an overview of the fabrication of various kinds of electrospun nanomaterials and their electrochemical properties. First, the electrospun CNFs as SC electrode materials will be widely discussed. Special attention will be paid to the relationship between the pore structure of the CNFs and their electrochemical properties. Second, metal oxide, metal sulfide, and metal nitride nanofibers with controllable architecture and composition for pseudocapacitors will be described. In the following, we will show that electrospun conducting polymer nanofibers and nanotubes can be used as flexible electrodes for construction of flexible SCs with both excellent electrochemical performance and flexibility. Finally, a consideration on the fabrication of electrospun composite nanomaterials will be presented prior to discussing some prospects in the enhancement of the electrochemical properties due to the synergistic effect.

sections.heading: 3.1. Controlling the Pore Structure in Electrospun CNFs
sections.text:
CNFs are usually produced by the conversion from electrospun polymeric nanofibers such as PAN, polyimide (PI), polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA), phenolic resin, poly(vinyliden fluoride) (PVDF), cellulose, pitch etc.[80,81] To
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1601301
R ev
ie w
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1601301 (6 of 43) wileyonlinelibrary.com
convert these electrospun polymeric nanofibers to CNFs, a carbonization process at a high temperature under an inert atmosphere is necessary. Electrospun PAN nanofibers are the most common carbon precursors for generating CNFs due to their high carbon yield and excellent thermal stability.[82] For synthesizing CNFs from PAN, it is essential to undergo a stabilization process before carbonization to keep the uniformity of the nanofibers and increase the thermal stability. For using CNFs as active electrode materials in SCs, it is important to increase the surface area and create suitable pores. Micro- and mesoporous are desired for EDLCs application because they facilitate the diffusion and (electro-)sorption of electrolyte ions, allowing high charge/discharge rates. The activation process will produce different gaseous species, such as CO2, CO, and CH4, which act as porogens leading to micro- and mesopores.[83]
Activation of CNFs with additional various types of oxidizing gases including steam, carbon dioxide and air, or a variety of chemical activating agents such as potassium hydroxide, phosphoric acid, sodium hydroxide is a facile and versatile approach for the creation of different types of pores with controllable concentration. For instance, porous structured PAN-based CNFs have been prepared by electrospinning, followed by the stabilization, carbonization, and activation with a steam (30 vol% in a flow of nitrogen gas) at a high temperature in the range of 700–800 °C.[84] It was found that the pore structure and the surface area of the PAN-based CNFs were strongly dependent on the activation temperature. When the activation temperature was set at 700 °C, microporous structured CNFs with a BET surface area of 1230 m2 g−1 were produced. On the other hand, CNFs that were activated at 800 °C displayed a BET surface area of 850 m2 g−1 consisting of mesopores. As a result, when used as electrode materials in EDLC, the 700 and 800 °C activated CNFs exhibited a higher capacitance at a low and high discharge current density, respectively (Figure 3a). This result indicates that the low resistance and the presence of mesopores in the CNFs play a key role for high current density applications, which is beneficial for practical capacitor applications. Figure 3b displayed ac impedance spectra for PAN-based CNFs calcined at various temperatures. It was found that the
resistance of the electrodes decreased with an increase in activation temperature. Moreover, an ideally straight line of the impedance slope at high activation temperature revealed the improved accessibility of the ions, which made a contribution to the good power density.
In addition to PAN, polybenzimidazol (PBI) was also used to prepare electrospun CNFs. After activation with a volume of 30% steam in a nitrogen gas at 800 °C, mesoporous and microporous CNFs were obtained, with BET surface area reaching up to 1220 m2 g−1, micropore volume to 0.71 cm3 g−1, mesopore volume to 0.20 cm3 g−1, and delivered capacitances up to 178 F g−1 at a discharge current of 5 mA using 30 wt% KOH aqueous electrolyte solution.[85] PBI-derived CNFs have also been tested as active electrode materials of EDLC in 1 m H2SO4 aqueous solution and displayed a specific capacitance of 202 F g−1 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2.[86] PI is another possible precursor for electrospun CNFs. A THF/methanol solution of poly(amic acid) (20 wt%) has been used as electrospinning precursor, followed by imidization by heating up to 350 °C, carbonization at 1000 °C, and finally activation at 650–800 °C in nitrogen gas flow containing 40 vol% steam.[87] The as-prepared PI derived CNFs activated at 750 °C showed the largest BET surface area of 1453 m2 g−1 and a micropore volume of 0.563 cm3 g−1. The high specific surface area provided high specific capacitance, with a maximum capacitance of 175 F g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1.
Generally, activation of CNFs with steam and CO2 is a socalled physical activation process. Porous CNFs have also been prepared via the chemical activation by reagents such as KOH and H3PO4. As shown in Figure 4a,b, CNFs paper with a smooth nanofiber morphology could be prepared by the activation of electrospun phenolic-based nanofibers with KOH.[88] Figure 4c showed the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms for the samples activated by different percentages of KOH. When the percentage of KOH was lower than 10 wt%, the adsorption quantity mainly took place at very low relative pressure (P/P0 < 0.02), suggesting the formation of highly microporous carbon. However, when the percentage of KOH was as high as 20 wt%, a small adsorption quantity

was observed at high relative pressure (P/P0 > 0.9), indicating the formation of small quantity of mesopores and macropores. The pore size distributions showed that most pores for all the samples were distributed at 0.7–1.2 nm (Figure 4d). In detail, when the percentage of KOH increased from 0 to 20 wt%, the BET surface area of the resultant CNFs increased from 524 to 1317 m2 g−1 and the average pore width increased from 1.74 to 2.12 nm. Meanwhile, Vmicro/Vtotal decreased from 96% to 77%, indicating an increase of the mesopores and macropores. The prepared porous CNF papers have been used as binder-free electrode for SCs, and CNF paper that was activated by 20 wt% KOH displayed a maximum specific capacitance of 362 F g−1 at a current density of 0.2 A g−1 in 6 m KOH aqueous electrolyte. When the current density increased from 0.2 to 20 A g−1, the capacitance retention was as high as 82%, indicating an excellent rate performance. In addition, high energy densities of the CNFs in both aqueous (7.1 W h kg−1) and organic electrolytes (27.9 W h kg−1) have been obtained. Similarly, H3PO4 activated porous CNFs derived from electrospun PAN nanofibers containing a small amount of H3PO4 (1 wt%) showed a large BET surface area of 709 m2 g−1, micropore volume of 0.278 cm3 g−1, and mesopore volume of 0.078 cm3 g−1.[89] Accordingly, a specific capacitance of 156 F g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and specific energy density of 10.98 W h kg−1 at a power density of 10 kW kg−1 were reported using 6 m KOH aqueous solution as electrolyte.
The pore structure of the CNFs has also been controlled by the carbonization of the electrospun polymer blends. The addition of cellulose acetate (CA) into PAN polymer solution led to controlled and fine pore architectures without activation process.[90] Compared to the pure PAN-derived CNFs, the BET surface area of CNFs derived from PAN/cellulose (15 wt%) increased from 740 to 1160 m2 g−1, with the micropore and mesopore surface area of 919 and 241 m2 g−1, respectively. Consequently, the capacitance of the prepared PAN/cellulose derived CNFs reached up to 245 F g−1 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 in 6 m KOH aqueous electrolyte solution, exhibiting 70% increase in comparison to that of PAN-based CNFs. A self-supported porous PI-based CNF membrane was prepared by electrospinning a blending polymer solution of PI and PVP and subsequent carbonization without activation process.[91] As shown in Figure 5a,b, the resultant PI-based CNFs exhibited BET surface area between 456 and 804 m2 g−1 and average pore size in the range of 0.7–2.0 nm. It was found that PVP mass loading have much influence on the BET surface area and the ultramicropore, supermicropore, and mesopore volumes. The maximum BET surface area of 804 m2 g−1 and total pore volume of 0.344 cm3 g−1 were obtained at an optimized PVP loading. Correspondingly, a maximun specific capacitance of 215 F g−1 was measured on the prepared PI-derived CNFs with current density of 0.2 A g−1 (Figure 5c). Furthermore, the PI-derived CNFs based SC exhibited an excellent electrochemical stability, maintaining 92% of the initial capacitance after 1000 cycles (Figure 5d). Nitrogen-enriched porous CNFs have been prepared from electrospun PAN nanofibers containing allyl polyethylene glycol (APEG) and followed by a carbonization process.[92] As a binder-free electrode in EDLC, the nitrogen-enriched porous CNFs showed a high specific capacitance of up to 302 F g−1 at a current density of 0.2 A g−1 in 6 m KOH aqueous solution due to the large BET surface area (753 m2 g−1) and the predominantly microporous structure.

The electrode also showed good cyclability for EDLC, retaining 94.6% of its initial capacitance after 2000 cycles. An energy density of 5.2 W h kg−1 and a power density of 10 kW kg−1 were achieved. Electrospun CNFs prepared from immiscible polymer blends of PAN/polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) (5 wt%) in N,N′-dimethyl formamide (DMF) followed by carbonization and CO2 activation at 1000 °C in helium have been used as electrodes in EDLC, exhibiting a ultrahigh BET surface area of 2419 m2 g−1.[93] A capacitance of 140 F g−1 under a current density of 1 A g−1 and energy densities of 67 and 101 W h kg−1 were obtained at 3.5 and 4 V in an ionic electrolyte of ethylmethylimidazolium bis (trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide (EMITFSI). PAN-based CNFs prepared by the stabilization, carbonization and steam activation of the blending PAN/pitch electrospun nanofibers at 900 °C gave a large specific surface area of 1877 m2 g−1 with a mesopore volume fraction of 50.8%, and displayed a capacitance of 144 F g−1 and a power density of 1300 W kg−1 in 6 m KOH aqueous electrolyte solution.[94]
Addition of inorganic salts such as ZnCl2 into electrospun PAN nanofiber has much influence on the pore structure of the prepared CNFs.[95] After the removal of the Zn traces by HCl, the resultant CNFs derived from the PAN/DMF solution containing 5 wt% ZnCl2 showed a BET surface area of 550 m2 g−1, micropore volume of 0.26 cm3 g−1, and mesopore volume of 0.10 cm3 g−1. While the BET surface area was only 310 m2 g−1 for CNFs delivered from PAN nanofibers containing 1 wt% ZnCl2, with a micropore and mesopore volumes of 0.15 and 0.03 cm3 g−1, respectively. Consequently, the specific capacitance of the CNFs increased from 120 to 140 F g−1 when the content of ZnCl2 was increased from 1 to 5 wt%. Similarly, the addition of Zn(Ac)2 also influenced the electrochemical performance of the resultant CNFs.[96] Porous CNFs have also been prepared by coaxial electrospinning Sn-PVP precursors in the core region and PAN/PVP precursors in the shell region, carbonization under N2, reduction with H2, and removal of Sn phase with acid treatment (Figure 6a).[97] As shown in Figure 6b, SEM image demonstrated the porous structure of the resultant CNFs. The specific surface area increased with the increasing of the Sn content, and the sample derived from carbon precursors containing 8 wt% SnCl2 showed a maximum BET surface area of 1082 m2 g−1, which was 2.3 times higher than that of conventional CNFs. In addition, the Sn-derived CNFs displayed a total pore volume and average pore diameters of 0.64 cm3 g−1 and 2.39 nm, respectively. The volume percentages of micropores and mesopores were 65.0% and 35.0%. The pore volume and the percentage of mesopores of the Sn-derived CNFs were 2.9 and 1.7 times higher than that of conventional CNFs. Figure 6c showed cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of all the Sn-derived CNFs (0, 1, 4, 8 wt% SnCl2) measured at 1 mV s−1 in the range of 0–1.0 V. Two redox peaks at 0.4–0.5 V were observed, indicating a pseudocapacitive behavior relative to faradic redox reactions, which could be attributed to oxygen functional groups on the surface of CNFs. As shown in Figure 6d, the Sn-derived CNFs (8 wt% SnCl2) showed a maximum specific capacitance (289 F g−1 at 10 mV s−1), which was 8.2 times higher than that of conventional CNFs. The principle of the EDLCs is based on the physical adsorption/desorption of electrolyte ions onto the electrode materials.

Among different types of pores in the CNFs, micropores show high surface areas, determining the large capacitance, while mesopores afford enhanced electrolyte penetration for high power density. Additionally, large spaces and macropores are also beneficial for electrolyte transport to micro- and mesopores to be adsorbed. The combination of multiple approaches allows to synthesize CNFs with macro-, meso- and micro-pores. For example, by using SiO2 as a template and KOH activation, hierarchical porous PAN-based CNFs displaying macro-, meso- and micro-porosity have been prepared (Figure 7a).[98] The SEM images clearly showed that pores were developed after SiO2 was removed by HF (Figure 7b,c). The obtained CNFs (derived from PAN/DMF solution containing 50 wt% SiO2) showed a BET surface area of 1632 m2 g−1, with a micropore volume of 0.60 cm3 g−1, a mesopore volume of 0.93 cm3 g−1, and macropore volume of 12.09 cm3 g−1. Compared to pure PANbased CNFs, the mesopore and macropore volume was significantly increased, providing fast ion mobility at high scan rates

(Figure 7d,e). As a result, the specific capacitances and retained capacitance ratio of the prepared CNFs by using 50 wt% SiO2 as template were higher than that of CNFs derived from individual PAN nanofibers. It is well known that poly(propylene oxide)-block-poly(ethylene oxide)-block-poly(propylene oxide) triblock copolymer (P123) is a typical template for the synthesis of mesoporous silica. By using P123 and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as mesoporous-inducing agents, PVP and phenolformaldehyde resins as carbon sources, nickel nitrate as the catalyst, porous CNFs have been prepared by electrospinning followed by carbonization in N2 and treatment with HNO3 and HF solutions.[99] With an optimized condition, the prepared CNFs (C-3.7@0.1) exhibited a maximum BET surface area of 1790 m2 g−1 and a total pore volume of 1.308 cm3 g−1. When used as electrodes for SCs, the optimized CNFs showed a high specific capacitance of 303 F g−1 at a current density of 0.7 A g−1, which should be due to their improved porous structure and graphitization degrees.
In addition to the examples as aforementioned, there are several other approaches to fabricate porous CNFs, such as i) by using different types of polymers as precursors, ii) the addition of other active materials in the carbon precursors, iii) solvent inducement, iv) plasma treatment, v) metal ion assistant acid corrosion process, etc.[100–143] Table 1 summarized a variety of strategies to prepare porous CNFs with information of the porous structure and the corresponding electrochemical performance in EDLC electrodes.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrospun Solid, Porous, and Hollow Metal Oxide
sections.text:
Nanofibers
There has been a fast growing development of various types of electrospun transition metal oxide nanofibers for SC electrodes in recent years.[144,145] Taking advantages of the large surface area and distinct reversible redox chemistry, electrospun nanofibers of pseudocapacitive transition metal oxides displayed extremely high specific capacitance values compared to CNF electrodes as EDLCs (Table 2).[146–185] Among all of the electrospun transition metal oxide nanofibers, RuO2 nanofibers display the highest capacity due to their high electronic conductivity and unique redox chemistry. For example, electrospun RuO2 nanofibers derived from RuO2 precursor/PVAc composite fibers possess a high electronic conductivity of 288 S cm−1.[146] To improve the transport of protons and charge storage capability, a thin hydrous RuO2 overlayer was introduced on the surface of electrospun RuO2 nanofibers through an electrodeposition process, which afforded a specific capacitance of 104 F g−1 in 1 m H2SO4 electrolyte solution. Furthermore, hydrous RuO2 coated electrospun RuO2 nanofibers showed an excellent long cycle performance, which maintained 87.2% of its original capacitance after 30 000 cycles.
MnO2 is another widely studied SC electrode material due to its good redox property, natural abundance and low cost. In general, MnOx nanofibers with a low oxidation state of Mn (x < 2) were usually produced by electrospinning followed by a thermal calcination process.[147–150] Sharma and co-workers demonstrated that the morphology of Mn3O4 could be controlled from nanofibers, to nanorods-, and nanoparticles by
adjusting the weight ratio of metal precursor to polymer during the electrospinning process (Figure 8a).[147] Increasing the weight ratio of metal to polymer precursor would increase the viscosity of the electrospun solution and improve the dispersion of Mn3O4 nanoparticles after calcination, resulting in a more dense nanofiber. On the contrary, individual Mn3O4 nanoparticles and nanorods would be formed when the weight ratio of metal precursor to polymer is smaller than 0.5:1. Benefiting from the porous nanostructured architecture, the Mn3O4 nanofibers synthesized with a ratio of metal precursor to poly mer of 1:1 showed a high specific capacitance value of 210 F g−1 and 155 F g−1 at 0.3 A g−1 in 1 m KCl and 1 m Na2SO4, respectively, and retained almost 100% of the initial capacitance after at least up to 500 cycles (Figure 8 b–e). This specific capacitance was also much higher than those of Mn3O4 nanorods (65 F g−1) and nanoparticles (58 F g−1). The electrochemical performance was mainly due to the porous nanofiber architecture with a large surface area. A recent study showed that the low oxidation state of Mn limits the high capacitance performance of electrospun MnOx nanofibers. To increase the valence of Mn in the MnOx nanofibers, a galvanostatic oxidation process has been employed to convert the electrospun Mn3O4 and Mn2O3 nanofibers to δ-MnO2 nanofibers.[148] The galvanostatically oxidized Mn3O4 (δ-MnO2) nanofibers delivered an excellent electrochemical performance of 380 F g−1 with a mass loading of 1.2 mg cm−2, which was much higher than that of as-calcined Mn3O4 nanofibers (250 F g−1).
The nanostrucuture and morphology of electrospun metal oxide fibers were usually strongly influenced by the calcination temperature. For example, electrospun V2O5 nanofibers with smooth and dense structure, spiral like structure, and flakylike structure have been fabricated by electrospinning followed by calcination in air at 300, 400, and 500 °C, respectively.[151] Accordingly, the morphology of the V2O5 nanofibers plays an important role on the electrochemical performance. Spiral like V2O5 nanofibers displayed a maximum capacitance of 190 F g−1 in KCl electrolyte, which was much higher than those of dense (25 F g−1) and flaky-like structured V2O5 nanofibers (86 F g−1) based SCs. In another reference, tubular V2O5 nanofibers have also been fabricated by electrospinning and the SC gave a capacitance of 210 F g−1 at current density of 1 mA cm−2 in 2 m KCl electrolyte.[152]
Perovskite-type metal oxides are also good candidates for SC electrodes due to their special electric conductivity and good electrochemical activity. For instance, LaxSr1–xCo0.1Mn0.9O3–δ (0.3 ≤ x ≤ 1) electrospun nanofibers gave a maximum specific capacitance of 485 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 in 1 m KOH aqueous electrolyte.[155] Similar perovskite nanostructures of electrospun LaxSr1–xCoO3–δ (0.3 ≤ x ≤ 1), LaxSr1–xNiO3–δ (0.3 ≤ x ≤ 1), LaxSr1–xCu0.1Mn0.9O3–δ (0.3 ≤ x ≤ 1) nanofibers have also been fabricated for SC electrode materials.[156–158]
In addition to the above reported typical pseudocapacitive electrodes, many papers have published on the so-called “pseudocapacitive behavior” of some metal oxides, hydroxides or sulfides. There is a point of view that such works on nickel- or cobalt-based compounds are especially misleading. Their electrochemical signatures, either by CV or galvanostatic measurements, are definitely not related to any pseudocapacitive behavior as they do not exhibit any relationship

between the charge (deltaQ) and potential (deltaV) changes, so that a capacitance equivalent to d(deltaQ)/d(deltaV) derivative can be formulated and experimentally measured.[159] Instead, they demonstrate a strong Faradaic behavior which has nothing to do with capacitance. A recent paper stressed the differences between these different behaviors.[160] Expressing the storage capabilities of such electrode materials in terms of capacitance (in F g−1 or F cm−2 or F m−3) is meaningless and capacity must be used instead (in C g−1 or mA h g−1, cm−2 or cm−3).
These materials are however of interest as they can be associated to a capacitive or pseudocapacitive electrode to build a “hybrid” device. Since the electrochemical signature of a hybrid device looks “capacitive,” a capacitance in F can be defined but
it does not reflect in any manner the behavior of the battery type electrode included in the device.
Wang and co-workers prepared NiO hollow nanotubes by electrospinning a mixed solution containing nickel nitrate, PVP, P123, citric acid, ethanol and water, followed by a calcination process at 500 °C in air.[161] The mechanism of the formation of NiO hollow nanotubes was attributed to the presence of citric acid. Nickel citrate produced when nickel nitrate was mixed with citric acid, interacts with the surfactants via hydrogen bonds on the surface of P123 micellar rod. The formed lamellar structure was limited by the molecular geometry and the large steric hindrance. During the calcination process to remove PVP, NiO hollow nanotubes were formed. The SEM and TEM images clearly showed the hollow structure of the resultant NiO

fibers with a shell thickness of about 17 nm (Figure 9a,b). Due to the hollow structure, NiO nanotubes showed a high BET surface area of 212 m2 g−1, which was twice as large as nanofibers synthesized with the similar approach in the absence of citric acid. Accordingly, NiO nanotubes exhibited a specific capacitance of 336 F g−1 (capacity of 39 mA h g−1), compared to only 136 F g−1 (capacity of 16 mA h g−1) for the NiO nanofibers (Figure 9c). Figure 9d showed the cyclic performance of the NiO nanotubes examined by galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements for 1000 cycles. The result exhibited that 87% of the initial capacitance were reserved, indicating an excellent cycle stability for a battery-type material. The improved electrochemical performance could be attributed to the hollow structure and the larger surface area, offering a faster ion and electron transfer. In addition to the morphology, the composition has also a large influence on the electrochemical performance of the NiO nanofibers. For example, La doped NiO nanofibers with a doping amount of 1.5% showed a capacity of 5.3 times higher than that of undoped NiO nanofiber electrode.[162] The enhancement of the capacity should be due to the improved conductivity, which was beneficial for reducing charge transfer resistance during the charge/discharge process. Co3O4 is another candidate as active electrode materials and has a high theoretical capacitance (3560 F g−1). In the past few years, a variety of Co3O4 nanomaterials including flakes, nanorods and nanowires have been prepared through coprecipitation, sol–gel, solvothermal, electrochemical and solid-state route.[166] However, the specific capacities of these nanomaterials are much lower than the capacity obtained with electrospun nanofibers. prepared Co3O4 nanofibers and demonstrated a specific capacitance of 407 F g−1 at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 (capacity of 62 mA h g−1), which was much higher than that of other Co3O4 nanomaterials-based electrodes.[167] Furthermore, the material displayed an excellent electrochemical stability, only a decay of 6% in specific capacity was observed after 1000 cycles. The electrochemical performance was attributed to the nanofiber morphology. The addition of P123 in the electrospun precursors allows to synthesize porous Co3O4 nanofibers.[168] The BET surface area of the porous Co3O4 nanofibers was much higher than that of Co3O4 nanofibers prepared without the addition of P123. Accordingly, the specific capacitance of 401 F g−1 at the current density of 5 mA cm−2 (capacity of 61 mA h g−1), which was 2.2 times as large as that of nonporous Co3O4 fibers.
Recently, a significant progress in the control of the architecture of electrospun Co3O4 nanofibers has been reported. The key point is the so-called gradient electrospinning process consisting of a gradient distribution of PVA molecular weights during the electrospinning process.[169] The low molecularweight PVA was located in the center, and the high molecularweight PVA was distributed in the outer layer. When electrospun PVA nanofibers containing cobalt precursors were heated, the inner low-weight PVA pyrolyzed and the cobalt species diffused to the middle/high molecular-weight PVA. This process caused the hollowing of the nanofibers leading to the formation of Co3O4 mesoporous nanotubes after the sintering in air (Figure 10a). TEM image exhibited that the resultant Co3O4 mesoporous nanotubes are uniform with a diameter of around 50 nm (Figure 10b). As shown in Figure 10c, the CVs displayed the exceptionally improved electrochemical performance of
the obtained Co3O4 mesoporous nanotubes. The as-prepared Co3O4 mesoporous nanotubes exhibited a stack capacitance of 25.0 F cm−3 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 (capacity of 4 mA h cm−3) (Figure 10d) and an outstanding cycling stability, maintaining 98% of the initial capacitance after 10 000 cycles (Figure 10e). All of these excellent electrochemical performances demonstrated the great application potential of the resultant Co3O4 mesoporous nanotubes.
In addition to NiO and Co3O4, other electroactive transition metal oxides such as Fe2O3, CuO, and TiO2 have lower theoretical capacitances/capacities. However, electrospun Fe2O3 and CuO nanofibers have also been tested as electrodes with discrete electrochemical performances due to their nanofiber-like structure.[170–172] For example, porous Fe2O3 nanofibers with a BET surface area of 61 m2 g−1, pore size and volume of 5.7 nm and 0.087 cm3 g−1, have been prepared by electrospinning.[170] Porous Fe2O3 nanofibers exhibited good electrochemical performance with specific capacitance of 348 F g−1 at a current density of 5 A g−1 in 1 m LiOH electrolyte (capacity of 48 mA h g−1), compared to nanograin structures with a capacitance of 102 F g−1 (capacity of 14 mA h g−1). Electrospun TiO2 nanofibers have also been prepared.[173,174] By using PVA-H3PO4 membrane as a solid electrolyte, a flexible SC was fabricated, which delivered a specific capacitance of 310 F g−1 (capacity of 43 mA h g−1).[173] The maximum energy density and maximum power density were 43.05 W h kg−1 and 2.798 W kg−1, respectively.
To improve the electrochemical performance of metal oxides-based battery-type materials, not only the architecture but also the composition needs to be controlled. Compared to transition metal oxides, spinels (AB2O4) containing two or

For example, electrospun ZnCo2O4 porous nanotubes were prepared by electrospinning followed by annealing in air.[175] On the one hand, the unique hollow and porous nanotube structure of ZnCo2O4 provided excellent electrolyte/electrode contact and efficient transport pathways in the SC electrode. On the other hand, it has revealed that ZnCo2O4 electrodes exhibited higher electrochemical activity and richer redox reactions than Co3O4.[176] Therefore, the electrospun ZnCo2O4 porous nanotubes-based SC showed a high specific capacitance of 770 F g−1 at 10 A g−1 in 6 m KOH aqueous solution, which was not only much higher than that of ZnCo2O4 nanoparticles-based SC, but also higher than individual Co3O4 and ZnO nanomaterials. Furthermore, the ZnCo2O4 porous nanotubes exhibited excellent rate property and good cycling stability. By applying single spinneret electrospinning technique followed by calcination, porous NiCo2O4 nanotubes have also been prepared and exhibited a high specific capacitance of 1647 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 in 2 m KOH aqueous solution (capacity of 183 mA h g−1), which could be attributed to the large specific surface area of the porous and hollow nanostructured NiCo2O4 material.[177] Recently, complex architectures of the spinel transition metal oxides including CoMn2O4, NiCo2O4, CoFe2O4, NiMn2O4, and ZnMn2O4 have been fabricated by using a single spinneret electrospinning technique.[178] By simply tuning the calcination

For example, Figure 11a,b showed typical SEM and TEM images of NiCo2O4 tube-in-tube structures. The resultant NiCo2O4 tubein-tube nanostructures display a high specific capacitance of 1756 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 in 2 m KOH aqueous solution (capacity of 220 mA h g−1), which was much higher than that of solid NiCo2O4 nanofibers and hollow nanotubes (Figure 11c–f).
In addition to aqueous solution, organic electrolyte has also been used for the fabrication of hybrid electrochemical devices. Recently, Li-ion hybrid electrochemical SC (Li-HEC) has attracted more and more attention because of higher energy density than a number of SCs and higher power density than most of Li-ion batteries.[180,181] Generally, the Li-HEC is composed of a Li-insertion type materials-based anode and large-surface-area carbonaceous materials-based cathode. Aravindan et al. demonstrated that electrospun TiNb2O7 nanofibers could be used as an insertion anode for Li-HEC with high energy and power densities.[182] The TiNb2O7 nanofibers were prepared by electrospinning a mixed solution containing PVP, titanium(IV) butoxide, niobium(V) ethoxide, ethanol and acetic acid, then followed by calcination at 1000 °C in air. The electrochemical performance of the Li-HEC was determined and the results were displayed in Figure 12. Figure 12a,b showed typical charge–discharge curves of Li-HEC comprised of AC/TiNb2O7 at various applied current densities and Ohmic drop of the AC/TiNb2O7 Li-HEC along with the commercial AC/Li4Ti5O12 Li-HEC configuration. The results showed a linear increase of dropping potential was obtained for the commercial AC/Li4Ti5O12 Li-HEC with increasing applied current density, whereas much less drop was observed for AC/TiNb2O7 Li-HEC. Furthermore, the Li-HEC exhibited a good cyclability, retaining 84% of the initial value after 3000 cycles (Figure 12d). Electrospun LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 nanofibers have also been used as spinel insertion electrode to construct Li-HEC with an AC counter electrode in an organic LiPF6-EC:DMC electrolyte.[183] The Li-HEC assembly delivered a maximum energy density of ≈19 W h kg−1 and showed a good cyclability of 3000 cycles with ≈16% loss of the initial value. Similarly, the asymmetric SC by using the electrospun LiNi0.4Co0.6O2 nanofibers as positive electrode and AC as negative electrode in 1 m LiPF6-EC:DMC electrolyte exhibited a specific capacitance of 73 F g−1.[184] The energy density and power density of the capacitor cell were about 180.2 W h kg−1 and 248.0 W kg−1, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrospun Hollow Metal Sulfide and Nitride Nanofibers
sections.text:
Recently, transition metal sulfide nanomaterials have emerged as a new class of SC and battery-type electrodes because of their high electrical conductivity, rich redox electrochemistry, complex structures, and valence states, which usually exhibit a large specific capacitance/capacity.[186–190] A variety of metal sulfides such as CuS, CoS, NiS, MoS2, and SnS have been investigated to be used as active materials for SC and battery-type electrodes with good results. Lou and co-workers demonstrated a versatile approach for the preparation of 1D MxCo3–xS4 (M = Ni, Mn, Zn) hollow nanotubes, using electrospun PAN nanofibers as a template.[191] Compared with other templates, the electrospun polymeric nanofiber template shows the advantages of uniform morphology, tunable diameter, flexible structure, abundant functional groups, and easy template removal. To generate MxCo3–xS4 hollow nanotubes, the electrospun PAN nanofibers with a diameter of about 200 nm were mixed with cobalt acetate and nickel acetate under reflux first, then M-Co acetate hydroxides were formed on the surface of PAN nanofibers. In the following step, the PAN/M-Co acetate hydroxide core–sheath nanofibers were converted to PAN/MxCo3–xS4 nanofibers through the sulfidation treatment with a thioacetamide solution. Finally, the hollow MxCo3–xS4 nanotubes were prepared by removal the PAN template with DMF. The resulting MxCo3–xS4 nanotubes displayed a uniform tubular structure with a sheath thickness of ≈50 nm and typical SEM and TEM images of the as-prepared MnCo2S4 nanotubes were presented in Figure 13a,b. The hollow structure of the MxCo3–xS4 nanotubes provided a large surface area and exceptional electrochemical performance as battery-type electrodes. Taking MnCo2S4 nanotubes as a typical example, a high specific capacitance of 1094 F g−1 (capacity of 152 mA h g−1) at 10 A g−1 was achieved. In addition, the MnCo2S4 nanotubes showed an excellent cyclability, retaining about 94% of the initial capacitance after 20 000 cycles (Figure 13c–f).

Transition metal nitrides such as TiN, MoN2, and VN are another class of promising active materials for pseudocapacitors due to their good electric conductivity, thermal and electrochemical stability, and low cost.[192–195] Among these metal nitrides, VN has been widely studied for its easy synthesis by a variety of synthetic strategies including ammonia reduction of V2O5, CVD, microwave plasma torch, etc. Recently, 1D VN hollow nanotubes have been prepared via an electrospinning technique combined with annealing and nitride processes, which could be used as high performance electrode materials for SCs.[194] The resulting hollow VN nanotubes were composed of nanoparticles with a porous structure. The BET surface area of the porous VN nanotubes that were calcined at 600 °C was 26.7 m2 g−1, with average pore size of 44 nm. They showed a maximum specific capacitance of 115 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 in 2 m KOH aqueous solution. However, an obvious capacitance fade was observed since only about 54% of the original capacitance was retained after 1000 cycles. The capacitance fade could be attributed to the oxidation of VN during cycling, leading to an increase of the resistance. It has been reported that the calcination temperature had also a significant influence on the electrochemical performance of the electrospun VN nanofibers electrode for SCs.[195] A specific capacitance as high as 292 F g−1 was achieved at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 when the calcination temperature was fixed at 800 °C.

sections.heading: 3.4. Electrospun Flexible Conducting Polymer Nanofiber Membrane
sections.text:
In the recent years, flexible energy devices including solar cells, batteries and SCs have attracted more and more attention due

to their potential applications in flexible displays and wearable electronic devices.[196,197] In particular, flexible solid state SCs possess the advantages of high flexibility, light weight, high specific energy and power densities, reliable safety, and environment-friendly characteristics, enabling them to be one of the most promising alternatives of energy storage devices.[26,198–203] In general, flexible electrodes with gel electrolytes are necessary for the construction of a flexible SC. Benefiting from the polymeric networks, the blending of PVA with ionic compounds (e.g., H3PO4, LiCl, KOH) with high ionic conductivity (10−4–10−2 S cm−1) is a class of typical gel electrolyte to meet the flexibility requirements in flexible SCs. The flexible electrode should possess an excellent mechanical strength, a high conductivity, and a superior electrochemical performance. In previous studies, a variety of nanomaterials such as carbons, metal oxides, polymers, and metal sulfides with various structures especially 1D nanostructures have been widely studied as flexible electrodes for SCs. Among them, conducting polymers possess many advantages including high electronic conductivity in their doping state, high voltage window, tunable redox activity, light weight, and low cost, and have therefore been regarded as good candidates for SC electrodes.[26,204,205] Conducting polymers offer a pseudocapacitance behavior through the redox process that can occur both on the surface and throughout the entire material, enabling high specific/volumetric energy and power densities. Typical conducting polymers such as PANI, PPy, PTh, and their corresponding derivatives have been used as active electrode materials for SCs.[206–208] Among them, PANI and PPy are usually in their p-doped state because the n-doping potential of PANI and PPy is much lower than the reduction potential of the electrolytes, while PTH and their derivatives can be both p- and n-doped. In addition, the electrospun electroactive conducting poly(triphenylamine) has also been used for pseudocapacitors, showing a higher cut-off voltage and energy density.[209]
Owing to the unique architecture, the electrospun conducting polymer nanofibers or nanotubes show an excellent electrochemical performance. More importantly, the electrospun conducting polymer nanofibers can be achieved as a selfsupported membrane with excellent conductivity and flexibility, which are suitable for the construction of binder free flexible solid-state SCs. As most of the conducting polymers are difficult to dissolve in common solvents, they are usually blending with some other polymers for electrospinning. On the other hand, the conducting polymer nanofiber can also be produced on the surface or within the template of electrospun nonelectroactive polymer nanofibers through an in situ polymerization process. For example, self-supported PAN supported PANI nanofibers have been prepared through electrospinning technique combined with an in situ polymerization process.[210] The prepared core–shell PAN@PANI nanofibers showed continuous and homogeneous characteristics, which were investigated by the photograph and SEM images (Figure 14a,b). As binder-free and freestanding electrode materials for flexible solid SCs, the core–shell PAN@PANI nanofibers gave specific capacitances of 151 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 (Figure 14c). The SC device also delivered a high energy density of 2.1 kW kg−1 at a power density of 2.1 kW kg−1 at 1.0 A g−1 (Figure 14d). The device showed an excellent flexible and cycling stability; only
tiny changes of the capacitance at various bending states and 2% loss of the initial specific capacitance were recorded after 1000 charge–discharge cycles (Figure 14e,f). By using electrospun nylon nanofiber-reiforced CA thin film as substrate, a flexbile and transparent electrode can also be prepared by in situ polymerization of PANI nanowires on the surface. The electrode exhibited an excellent electrochemical performance with a specific capacitance of 402 F g−1.[211] Electrospun poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) nanofiber nonwoven mats have also been used as active materials for the fabrication of flexible solid state SCs.[212] PEDOT/PVP nanofibers were prepared via electrospinning and vapor phase polymerization. After the removal of PVP with methanol, PEDOT nanofibers with diameters around 350 nm were generated. The PEDOT nanofibers show a high conductivity of 60 ± 10 S cm−1. The flexible solid state SC has been processed by using carbon cloths as current collector, PEODT nanofiber membrane as active materials, PAN nanofiber membrane as the separator, and PVDF-co-HFP/ionic liquid mixture as solid electrolyte. However, the electrochemical performance was not as good as that of other conducting polymer-based SCs, the device possesses a capacitance of only about 20 F g−1 based on the active materials. Therefore, it is still challenging to obtain interesting electrochemical performance in terms of specific capacitance and cycling stability for flexible conducting polymer electrodes.

sections.heading: 3.5. Electrospun Composite Nanofibers with Designed Architectures
sections.text: Just as mentioned, a variety of electrospun nanofibers including CNFs, metal oxides, metal nitrides, and conducting polymers with controllable architectures have been developed for highperformance SCs. However, these single-phased electrospun nanofibers usually possess disadvantages in some aspects. For example, as EDLC electrode materials, CNFs show a low specific capacitance and low energy density. For metal oxide and nitride nanofibers, the rate capability and power density are also unsatisfactory due to their relatively low electrical conductivity. Finally, a poor stability is the most serious drawback for conducting polymer electrode materials. Electrospun composite nanomaterials with at least two components can combine the desired properties of both materials classes and minimize their drawbacks.[213]

sections.heading: 3.5.1. CNFs-Based Electrospun Composite Nanofibers
sections.text:
In this section, we will present an overview of the preparation of a variety of CNFs-based electrospun composite nanofibers including CNFs/carbons, CNFs/metals, CNFs/metal oxides, CNFs/carbides, and CNFs/conducting polymers and their electrochemical properties. The influence of the addition of CNFs on the electrochemical performance of the composite nanofibers will be fully discussed.
CNFs-Based Electrospun Composite Nanofibers Containing Other Types of Carbon: It has been discussed that porous CNFs are one of the most important electrode materials for SC due to their large surface area, high pore volume and tunable pore size, and
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1601301

high electrical conductivity. To further increase the specific capacitance and energy density, the addition of other active components in the CNFs is an effective way.[214–287] For example, the combination of graphene, carbon nanotubes, and other types of carbon materials in CNF electrodes might enhance their electrochemical performance. Among various types of carbon materials, the introduction of graphene not only increases the electrical conductivity of the electrospun CNFs, but also influences their architecture. Wang and co-workers demonstrated that the CNFs/graphene composite exhibited much rougher and more porous structure than pristine CNFs.[214] The CNFs decorated by the single or few layered graphenes were less aggregated, which was favorable for electrolyte penetration into the layer of the nanocomposites. Accordingly, the CNFs/graphene possessed a higher BET surface area of 480 m2 g−1 as well as higher conductivity (65.9 S cm−1) compared to pristine CNFs. CNFs/graphene composites displayed also an enhanced specific capacitance of 183 F g−1 at a current density of 1.0 A g−1, 1.6 times as large as that of CNFs. Furthermore, the CNF/graphene composites also exhibited excellent cycle life stability. The capacitance retention was ≈92% after 4500 charge–discharge cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1, while a 75.6% capacitance retention was achieved after 2000 cycles for CNFs. Some other examples of CNF/graphene composites have also been published.[215–219] It seems that the “plane-to-line” structure of CNF/graphene composites is more favorable for SC electrodes because of the good electron transfer and easy diffusion of the hydrated ions.[216] By constructing a “plane-to-line” conducting network and by introducing nitrogen doping, a specific capacitance of 338 F g−1 at 1 mV s−1 in 1 m NaCl was achieved, which was about 1.97 times as large as pristine CNFs.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2016, 1601301

Similar to graphene, the addition of carbon nanotubes has also an influence on the physical properties and architecture of the CNFs. Hou and co-workers demonstrated the fabrication of CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers through the electrospinning of a PAN solution containing MWCNT, followed by the calcination and activation processes.[220] As shown in Figure 15a,b, the CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers displayed a rough surface and porous architecture, and the MWCNT were both embedded and exposed on the surface of CNFs. Benefiting from the unique architecture and high conductivity (5.32 S cm−1), the prepared CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers delivered a specific capacitance of 310 F g−1 at a current density of 0.1 A g−1, which was about 1.8 times as large as that of pristine CNFs (Figure 15c). Moreover, CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers based SC exhibited a long cycle durability, with a capacitance retention of ≈97% after 1000 cycles (Figure 15d). By electrospinning a PVA solution containing starch, MWCNTs, para-toluenesulfonic acid, and sodium dodecyl sulfate, and followed calcination process, a highly porous CNF/ MWCNT composite nanofibers with the embedded and protruded CNTs were produced.[221] The CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers showed a specific capacitance of 170 F g−1 in 1 m H2SO4, which was higher than that of PAN derived CNFs. The CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers can also been generated by employing cellulose (CA) as the carbon precursor.[222] The addition of 6% MWCNT led to an increase of the specific surface area from ≈870 to ≈1120 m2 g−1. The specific capacitance of the CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers was ≈145 F g−1, compared with that of the pristine CNFs of 105 F g−1. The enhanced specific capacitance could be attributed to the unique architecture and high conductivity of the CNF/MWCNT composite nanofibers. A specific capacitance as high as 417 F g−1 could even be achieved via the addition of SWCNTs instead of MWCNTs into the electrospun CNFs.[223] Hierarchical nanostructured CNFs grafted with CNTs were fabricated through a vapor growth technique by using C2H2 as carbon source and Ni nanoparticles on CNFs as catalysts.[226] The hierarchical CNF/CNT electrode showed a specific capacitance of 185 F g−1 at the discharge current density of 0.625 A g−1 in PVA/H3PO4 gel electrolyte. At a higher discharge current density of 2.5 A g−1, the specific capacitance was 114 F g−1, indicating a good rate capability. Vertically aligned carbon nanotubes (VACNTs) have also been grown on the surface of electrospun CNFs by pyrolysis, which lead to a uniform hierarchical structure.[227] By introducing additional PVP as carbon source, dense VACNTs were uniformly distributed on the surface of electrospun CNFs (Figure 16a,b). In order to obtain a wide electrochemical windows and high energy density, an ionic liquid electrolyte (EMIMBF4) was used, and a specific capacitance of about 147 F g−1 was obtained at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 (Figure 16c). Thanks to the high operation voltage, the VACNTs/CNFs composite nanofibers delivered an ultrahigh energy density of 98.8 W h kg−1 at a current density of 1.0 A g−1 at 60 °C (Figure 16d). The VACNTs/CNFs composite nanofibers exhibited excellent cycle life stability, with capacitance retention of ≈97% after 20 000 charge–discharge cycles (Figure 16e). In addition, the VACNTs/CNFs composite nanofibers-based SCs showed a good flexibility and the structural integrity under

Activated carbon nanowhiskers (ACNWs) wrapped electrospun CNFs with 3D porous structure has been fabricated through the calcination of PANI nanowhiskers on CNFs.[228] The prepared ACNWs/CNFs composite material showed an excellent electrochemical performance in terms of power density at high current density and of cycling stability. The power density was about 252.8 kW kg−1 at a current density of 800 A g−1 and almost no capacitance loss was observed after 10 000 charge–discharge cycles. Graphene-like carbon nanowalls (GNW) can be directly grown on some special substrate via microwave plasma-enhanced CVD approach. By using CH4/ H2 as precursors, GNW has been constructed on the surface
of CNTs that were directly grown on the electrospun CNFs, forming a dendritic architecture.[229] The prepared GNW/CNTs/ CNFs composite nanofibers showed a specific capacitance of 176 F g−1 at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, which was much higher than that of pristine CNFs (56 F g−1). The addition of both graphene oxide and CNTs into the CNFs has also been proposed for SCs electrodes. The enhanced electrochemical performance was attributed to the peculiar architecture and the synergistic effect between the various components.[230]
Electrospun CNFs/Metal Composite Nanofibers: The introduction of metal nanoparticles into CNFs can, not only influence their architecture, but also increase their electrical conductivity. The most frequently used metals within or on the surface of electrospun CNFs include Ni, Co, Cu, Pt, Ru, Ag, Ru-Ag.[231–242]

The addition of Ni nanoparticles (22.4 wt%) into the electrospun CNFs produced a rough morphology with the Ni nanoparticles being incorporated into the CNFs.[231] The resultant CNFs/Ni composite nanofibers showed an enhanced specific capacitance of 164 F g−1 at 0.25 A g−1 in 6 m KOH compared with that of pristine CNFs of 50 F g−1. Carbon nanorods/Co composite nanorods have also been prepared through a similar electrospinning technique and calcination process, where Co nanoparticles with a size from 20 to 100 nm were embedding in carbon nanorods.[234] The prepared carbon nanorods/Co (10% Co) composites exhibited a specific capacitance of 159 F g−1 at a discharge current of 0.25 mA in 0.5 m H2SO4, which is 44 times as large as pristine carbon nanorods. Compared with Ni and Co nanoparticles, it seemed that the introduction of Cu nanoparticles with a size of about 30 nm in CNFs led to enhanced performances.[235] The CNFs/Cu composite nanofibers delivered a specific capacitance of about 183 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 in 6 m KOH, an energy density of 2.7 W h kg−1, and power density of 518 W kg−1. In addition, the existence of both Cu nanoparticles and CNTs further enhanced the specific capacitance of the composite nanofibers to 225 F g−1 with an energy density of 2 W h kg−1 and power density of 1916 W kg−1.[236]
A little different from the Ni, Co and Cu nanoparticles in electrospun CNFs, the sizes of noble metal nanoparticles that are introduced in CNFs usually possess a smaller diameter. For example, Pt nanoparticles with a small size of 7–10 nm can be well incorporated in electrospun porous CNFs (PCNFs) through
an electrospinning technique and calcination treatment (inset of Figure 17a).[237] The prepared PCNFs/Pt composite nanofibers showed a large surface area of 670 m2 g−1, which was 1.5 and 2.7 times higher than that of nonporous CNFs and CNFs/Pt (Figure 17a). The PCNFs/Pt composite nanofibers also exhibited low electrical resistance of 1.7 × 103, leading to a high specific capacitance of 130 F g−1 at a current density of 0.2 A g−1 (Figure 17b), an energy density of 16.9–15.4 W h kg−1 at a power density ranging from 555–27 843 W kg−1 (Figure 17c), and an excellent cycling durability with a capacitance retention of 93% after 3000 cycles (Figure 17d). Through an electrospinning, carbonization, and activation processes, Ru nanoparticles with a size from 2 to 15 nm have been embedded in the CNFs to form CNFs/Ru composite nanofibers.[238] The resultant CNFs/Ru (7.31 wt% Ru) showed a high specific capacitance of 391 F g−1, compared with that of CNFs without Ru loading (140 F g−1). The XRD pattern indicated that Ru nanoparticles would change to hydrous RuO2 during the oxidation scan. Ru-Ag alloy nanoparticles with a much smaller size of 2–4 nm have also been demonstrated to disperse on the surface of electrospun CNFs after a post-synthesis reduction treatment.[239] The specific capacitance of the resultant CNFs/Ru-Ag composite nanofibers can reach 350 F g−1 at 100 mV s−1 in 0.5 m H2SO4, which is 15 times as large as that of single CNFs electrode.
Electrospun CNFs/Metal Oxide Composite Nanofibers: We have shown that transition metal oxides with 1D solid and hollow
