nanostructures are one of the most important pseudocapacitor materials due to their rich reversible redox reactions (Section 3.2). However, they are often suffering from low electrical conductivity and poor electrochemical stability. To overcome these deficiencies, transition metal oxides are usually combined with electrospun CNFs to form composites in various architectures. Taking the advantages of the high conductivities of CNFs and the rich redox chemistry of transition metal oxides, CNFs/transition metal oxide composite nanofibers have become promising electrode materials for high performance SCs.[243–287] For example, CNFs/RuO2 composite nanofibers with hollow core architecture have been fabricated by electrospinning followed by a thermal treatment.[244] Owing to the unique textured and hollow structure, large surface area, and uniform dispersion of small RuO2 nanoparticles, the CNFs/RuO2 (13.72 wt% RuO2) composite nanofibers delivered a specific capacitance of 180 F g−1 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 in 6 m KOH aqueous solution, 2.25 times as large as that of pristine CNF electrodes. In addition, the energy density reached 20–14 W h kg−1 at the power density ranging from 400 to 10 000 W kg−1, which was also much higher than that of pristine CNF electrodes (2 W h kg−1 at a power density of 4000 W kg−1).
CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers have been one of the most widely studied electrode materials for SCs due to the high theoretical specific capacitance, environmentally benign nature and low cost of active MnOx and high conductivity and flexibility of CNFs. The most common and simple approach for the fabrication of CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers was the electrospinning of a solution containing carbon precursor and an Mn salt (or MnOx nanoparticles), followed by a controlled heat treatment.[245–248] However, such a strategy usually led to the formation of an architecture composed of active MnOx nanoparticles inside CNFs, hindering them to contact with the electrolyte. As a result, the CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers display a relatively low electrochemical performance. Recently, in order to enhance the specific capacitance and cycling stability of the CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers, a 3D nanohybrid architectures consisting of CNFs/MnOx nanofibers and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) sheets have been fabricated and the preparation process has been illustrated in Figure 18a.[249] By introducing phase-separated polymers and manganese ions as precursors, manganese ion/PVP sheathed PAN nanofibers could be prepared. Then, after the calcination, nanometer-size MnOx particles were mainly dispersed on the surface of CNFs. The TEM image exhibited that the size of the MnOx nanoparticles was 15 ± 5 nm (Figure 18b). Figure 18c showed a typical cross-sectional SEM image of the CNFs/MnOx/RGO nanohybrids (RGO 50 wt%), demonstrating the formation of 3D architectures consisting of CNFs/MnOx nanofibers and RGO nanosheets. In this unique architecture, the RGO nanosheets acted as a conductive channel, and CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers enabled an efficient ion and charge transfer. As shown in Figure 18d, the specific capacitance of the nanohybrid electrode increased gradually with increasing the content of RGO, the electrode with 50 wt% RGO exhibited a maximum specific capacitance of 174 F g−1 compared with the individual CNFs/MnOx composite nanofibers and pristine RGO nanosheets. On the other hand, in the case of CNFs/MnOx/ GO nanohybrids (without the reduction of GO), the specific
capacitance decreased gradually with increasing the content of GO (Figure 18e), indicating the internal resistance of the electrode (Figure 18f). The calculated data of the capacitance for the two samples are shown in Figure 18g,h. In addition, the CNFs/MnOx/RGO nanohybrid electrode exhibited an excellent long cycle life, with only ≈9% capacitance loss over 500 cycles (Figure 18i).
CNFs/MnOx composites with a coaxial structure has been proved to be an ideal candidate for construction of high performance SCs.[250–257] The thin coating layer of active MnOx materials on the surface of CNFs with good electrical connection ensure the high utilization of MnOx, leading to a superior electrochemical performance. Coaxial CNFs/MnO2 nanofibers are usually synthesized by the in situ electrochemical deposition of MnO2 onto CNFs. The loading amount of MnO2 on the surface of CNFs can be well controlled by varying the reaction time. Through such a strategy, a core–shell hierarchical nanostructure consisting of CNFs and MnO2 nanowhiskers has been prepared.[250] It has been found that the average specific capacitance of the prepared coaxial CNFs/MnO2 nanofibers decreased with the increasing of the deposition time. When the deposition time was fixed to 5 min, a maximum specific capacitance of 557 F g−1 was achieved at a current density of 1 A g−1. The coaxial CNFs/MnO2 nanofibers also exhibited excellent long term cyclability, with the capacitance retention ≈94% after 1500 charge–discharge cycles. The architecture of the coaxial CNFs/MnO2 nanofibers is vital for their electrochemical performances, thus various structures of CNFs/MnO2 nanofibers including porous, hollow, and multichannelled architectures have been developed for fabricating high performance SCs.[254–257] For instance, Jang and co-workers demonstrated the fabrication of multidimensional MnO2 nanohairdecorated multichannel CNFs as electrode materials for SC.[257] Figure 19a illustrated the process for the preparation of MnO2 nanohair-decorated multichannel CNFs through a single-nozzle co-electrospinning. Figure 19b–e showed the TEM image of the CNFs and the prepared CNFs/MnO2 composite nanofibers, demonstrating that multichannel nanostructure still existed even after the deposition of MnO2 nanohair on the surface of CNFs. And with the reaction time, the density of MnO2 nanohair growth increased. This unique architecture provided the advantages of large surface area, high electrical conductivity, faster charge transport and improved electrolyte ion diffusion. Therefore, the MnO2 nanohair-decorated multichannel CNFs exhibited excellent electrochemical properties. Figure 19f showed the CV curves of the four samples, demonstrating the combination of Faradaic reation from MnO2 and double-layered capacitance derived from CNFs for the CNFs/MnO2 composite samples. Galvanostatic charge–discharge curves revealed that a superhigh specific capacitance of 855 F g−1 at a current density of 2 A g−1 , obtained for the sample of CNFs/MnO2 composite nanofibers (reaction time of 60 min), which was much higher than that of pristine CNFs without MnO2 decoration (188 F g−1) (Figure 19g,h). Furthermore, a good cycle stability (87.3% capacitance retention after 5000 cycles) was also achieved (Figure 19i). As aforementioned, the introduction of CNTs into CNFs was good strategy to increase their electrochemical performance. Actually, the deposition of active MnO2 materials on the surface of CNFs/CNTs composite nanofibers

has also displayed an enhanced electrochemical performance compared with that of CNFs/MnO2 composites since the addition of CNT influences the architecture and the intrinsic conductivity of the CNFs/CNTs/MnO2 composite nanofibers.[258,259] Recently, a ternary hierarchical MnO2/conducting PPy@CNFs composite nanofibers have been used as electrode materials for capacitors.[260] Different from the above synthetic strategy for the deposition of MnO2, the 1D triaxial MnO2/conducting PPy@CNFs composite nanofibers were prepared via a in situ interfacial redox reaction between pyrrole monomer and KMnO4 in the presence of CNFs. This unique architecture gave a high specific capacitance of 705 F g−1 at 2 mV s−1, and a high areal capacitance of 1.4 F cm−2. CNFs/NiO composite nanofibers can be prepared by depositing Ni(OH)2 on the CNFs and then followed by a calcination process, while the CNFs were synthesized via electrospinning a solution consisting of PAN, GO and PANI followed by a heat treatment.[261] It was found that the morphology of the CNFs/ NiO composite nanofibers was much influenced by the calcination temperature. The sample calcinated at 400 °C possessed a rough morphology and NiO nanoparticles with a diameter of 7.8 nm were decorated on the surface of CNFs, while a larger

size of 12.7 nm was achieved under a calciation at 500 °C. Correspondingly, the specific capacitance of CNFs/NiO composite nanofibers calcined at 400 °C was much higher than that at 500 °C. Coaxial NiO/CNFs have been prepared through an electrospinning, vapor deposition polymerization, and carbonization processes.[262] The thickness of the carbon layer that converted from PPy could be controlled by tuning the concentration of the initiator solution. The prepared coaxial NiO/CNFs (3 nm thickness of carbon) showed a specific capacitance of ≈288 F g−1 at a current density of 0.3 A g−1 in 1 m KOH aqueous solution, which was higher than pristine NiO nanofibers (≈221 F g−1) and carbon nanotubes (121 F g−1). Similar to CNFs/NiO composite nanofibers, electrospun CNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers have also been used as electrode materials in SCs and batteries.[263–265] For example, 1D heterostructured CNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers with beta-Ni(OH)2 nanoplates on the surface of CNFs has been reported.[263] The amount of Ni(OH)2 nanoplates on the surface of CNFs could be tuned by adjusting the Ni(Ac)2 precursor concentration. When a certain amount of Ni(Ac)2 precursors was used, uniform hexagon Ni(OH)2 nanoplates were grown on the surface of CNFs. The resultant CNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers exhibited a higher specific capacitance of 76.5 F g−1 (696 F g−1 based on the mass of Ni(OH)2) at a current density

of 4 A g−1 (capacity of 11 mA h g−1 for the CNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite electrode and 97 mA h g−1 when based on the mass of Ni(OH)2) than that of CNFs, pure Ni(OH)2 nanoplates, and their physical mixture. N-doped CNFs (NCNFs)/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers have also been prepared by a two-step solid reaction between cellulose/PPy coaxial nanofibers derived NCNFs and dried Ni(Ac)2 precursors. The hybrid electrochemical capacitor (HEC) device by using the NCNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers as positive electrode and NCNFs as negative electrode exhibited a high working voltage of 1.6 V and a specific capacitance as high as ≈1045 F g−1 at 1 mV s−1 (capacity of 174 mA h g−1), which was much higher than that of N-CNFs. Moreover, the HEC device exhibited an energy density as high as ≈51 W h kg−1 and power density of ≈117 kW kg−1.[265]
A unique flexible 3D hierarchical porous hybrid film composed of intercrossed CNFs/Co3O4 composite nanofibers have been prepared.[267] Interestingly, the Co3O4 nanoparticles with off-center hollow voids architecture have been well dispersed in CNFs. The CNFs/Co3O4 hybrid film delivered a high discharge specific capacitance of 552 F g−1 (1491 F g−1 based on the mass of Co3O4) at a current density of 1 A g−1 in 6 m KOH aqueous solution (capacity of 77 mA h g−1 for the CNFs/Co3O4 composite electrode and 207 mA h g−1 when based on the mass of Co3O4), which was about 20 times higher than that of pristine CNFs. The hybrid film electrode also exhibited an excellent rate capability at higher current densities. About 72% of the specific capacitance was retained when the current density increased to 12 A g−1. In addition, the hybrid film electrode showed a remarkable electrochemical stability, and there was almost no loss of the specific capacitance after 2000 cycles. CNFs/Co3O4 composite nanofibers with a solid morphology of Co3O4 nanoparticles also showed a good electrochemical performance.[268] Similar to CNFs/Ni(OH)2 composite nanofibers aforementioned, a flexible and freestanding electrospun CNFs/Co(OH)2 composite paper has been reported.[269] Co(OH)2 nanoparticles were well dispersed on the surface of CNFs to form a nanoparticle-adhering-nanofiber architecture. However, the specific capacitance was found to be only 132 F g−1 at discharge current density of 1 A g−1 (capacity of 18 mA h g−1), which was much lower than that of reported CNFs/Co3O4 composite nanofibers.
Electrospun CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers with various architectures have been regarded as promising electrode materials.[270–274] Generally, the CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers were fabricated through the heat treatment of the electrospun PAN nanofibers containing VO(acac)2 precursor or V2O5 nanoparticles. For example, a flexible nonwoven film composed of CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers were prepared by using VO(acac)2 as the metal oxide precursor.[272] With the addition of V2O5 component, the surface of CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers became rougher and a large number of pores with a small size of 1 nm were observed. The CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers electrode showed a specific capacitance of 463 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 and retained the capacitance of 380 F g−1 at even 10 A g−1, indicating the high capacitance and excellent rate capability. The electrochemical stability of the CNFs/V2O5 composite nanofibers electrode was also promising because there was no capacitance loss after 5000 charge–discharge cycles. The CNFs/V2O5 nanofibers with core–sheath architecture have also been fabricated by electrodeposition.[274]
The thickness of the V2O5 layer on the surface of CNFs could be well controlled by the numbers of deposition cycles. The unique core–sheath structure with a very thin layer (about 3 nm) of V2O5 allowed for the efficient utilization of V2O5 and high conductivity, which gave a high specific capacitance of 463 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1. When the current density increased to 10 A g−1, the specific capacitance still retained 380 F g−1. Additionally, a CNFs/V2O5 nanofibers electrode also exhibited excellent cycling stability, maintaining a specific capacitance of 400 F g−1 at a current density of 5 A g−1 for up to 5000 cycles.
Electrospun CNFs/Fe3O4 composite nanofibers with Fe3O4 nanosheets attaching on the surface of CNFs have been prepared by electrospinning followed by solvothermal reaction.[275] SEM image of the CNFs/Fe3O4 composite nanofibers showed that Fe3O4 nanosheets were uniformly deposited on the surface of CNFs (Figure 20a). On the one hand, highly dispersed Fe3O4 nanosheets provided high level exposure of Fe3O4 surface, increasing the utilization of the active Fe3O4. On the other hand, the high electrical conductivity of the CNFs decreased the charge transfer resistance of Fe3O4 component effectively. Therefore, the CNFs/Fe3O4 composite nanofibers showed much higher electrochemical activity than the CNFs, indicating that Fe3O4 contributed to most of the capacitance of the composite electrode (Figure 20b). In addition, the CNFs/Fe3O4 composite nanofibers electrode displayed a higher specific capacitance (135 F g−1) than pure Fe3O4 (83 F g−1) as revealed by galvanostatic charge–discharge curves, and an excellent long cycle life (91% of capacitance retention after 1000 cycles) (Figure 20c,d). By employing a similar synthetic strategy, heterostructured CNFs/SnO2 composite nanofibers have been fabricated, which exhibited a maximum specific capacitance of 187 F g−1 at a scan rate of 20 mV s−1 in 1 m H2SO4 solution.[276] Additionally, the specific capacitance retention of the electrodes was over 95% after 1000 cycles, indicating their excellent electrochemical stability.
Recently, binary layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have been studied due to their high redox activity and low cost.[277,278] By combination with CNFs, the electrochemical performance can be further improved due to the superior electrical conductivity. For example, Liu and co-workers demonstrated the fabrication of CNFs/nickel-cobalt (Ni-Co) LDH composite nanofibers through electrospinning followed by a one-step solution codeposition approach.[279] By using different auxiliary agents, a nanorod and ultrathin nanosheet like morphologies of Ni-Co LDH were well grown on the surface of CNFs (Figure 21a,b). It was found that the architecture of the resultant CNFs/Ni-Co LDH nanocomposites had much influence on the electrochemical performance. The CNFs/Ni-Co LDH nanorod composites exhibited a specific capacitance of 1378 F g−1 (capacity of 153 mA h g−1 based on Ni-Co LDH mass) at a current density of 1 A g−1 in 1 m NaOH solution. While a specific capacitance of 1195 F g−1 (capacity of 133 mA h g−1) was achieved for the CNFs/ Ni-Co LDH nanosheet composites (Figure 21c). Both of the two electrodes showed a good cycling stability (Figure 21d). The high electrochemical performance should be due to the unique structure of the CNFs/Ni-Co LDH composite nanofibers, which provided fully exposed active sites, improved specific surface area, and high electrical conductivity. CNFs/metal oxide composite nanofibers and their composites with other components with a complex architecture have also been reported as electrode materials for SCs, and their electrochemical performance has been summarized in Table 3. It should be mentioned that the addition of some inactive oxides such as silica and ZnO into the CNFs will also enhanced the electrochemical performance because of more pores generated and the largely increased specific surface area.[288–297] Specially, electrospun CNFs/metal oxide composite nanofibers are also good candidates as electrodes for Li-HEC.[298–300] For example, unique CNFs/Li4Ti5O12 composite nanofibers with a highly porous architecture have been prepared and exhibited ultrahigh rate capability and superior cycling stability. By employing CNFs/Li4Ti5O12 composite nanofibers as anode material and CNFs film as cathode, the Li-HEC device displayed a maximum specific energy density of 50.3 W h kg−1 at a specific power density of 225 W kg−1, which was among the highest value reported for SC and Li-HEC systems.
Electrospun CNFs/Carbide Composite Nanofibers: Recently, electrospun TiC-based nanocomposites have been shown to be an attractive kind of SC electrodes due to their good electronic conductivity and excellent stability.[301,302] TiC/CNFs have been fabricated via the chlorination of the electrospun TiC nanofibers.[301] The resultant TiC/CNFs showed a high specific surface area of 1390 m2 g−1 and an average pore size of ≈1 nm. Both graphitic carbon and highly disordered carbon have been found to surround TiC nanocrystallites. Additionally, the as-prepared TiC/CNFs exhibited a mechanically flexible characteristic, and thus, could be used as electrode materials for binder-free SCs. The electrochemical measurements displayed that gravimetric capacitances of 110 F g−1 and 65 F g−1 were achieved in aqueous 1 m H2SO4 and organic 1.5 m TEA-BF4 electrolytes, respectively, at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. Furthermore, the TiC/ CNFs-based SC electrode showed a high rate performance since a fade of only 15% of the capacitance was observed in 1 m H2SO4 when the scan rate increased to 1 V s−1. The TiC/CNFs could also be prepared by the direct stabilization and carbonization of electrospun tetrabutyl titanate/PVP composite nanofibers.[302] It was found that the products which were stabilized in air contain much less TiC nanoparticles than that stabilized in Ar. The size of the TiC nanoparticles in the CNFs was about 10–30 nm. The specific surface areas of the TiC/CNFs stabilized in Ar and air were 116.5 and 340.1 m2 g−1, respectively. Accordingly, the two TiC/CNFs -based SC electrodes showed specific capacitances of 68 and 98 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1, respectively. Moreover, both the TiC/CNFs-based SC electrodes displayed an enhanced specific capacitance compared with that of pure TiC nanoparticles (26 F g−1) and CNFs (3.2 F g−1). In addition, the two corresponding TiC/CNFs-based SC electrodes exhibited an excellent long-term cycling performance, with capacitance retentions of 98.9% and 93% after 25 000 cycles at a current density of 10 A g−1, respectively.
Electrospun CNFs/Conducting Polymer Composite Nanofibers: The electrospun conducting polymer nanofiber membrane has been proven to be good candidate as flexible and binderfree electrode material for SCs. The introduction of conducting polymers onto flexible electrospun CNF membrane will not only maintain its flexibility, but also enhance its electrochemical performance due to a synergistic effect. The flexible paper
composed of CNFs/conducting PANI composite nanofibers with a core–sheath structure can be fabricated through an in situ rapid mixture polymerization approach.[303] The CNFs/ PANI paper consisted of overlapped and crossed nanofibers with small-compact PANI nanoparticles on the surface of nanofibers (Figure 22a,b). Due to the introduction of PANI, the electrical conductivity of the CNFs/PANI paper was higher than that of pristine CNFs and individual PANI. The CV curves of the CNFs/PANI paper was also distinct from the electric double-layer capacitance, showing two couples of redox peaks which were attributed to semiconducting-conducting and emeraldine-pemigraniline transitions (Figure 22c). From the galvanostatic charge–discharge curves, the specific capacitance of composite material (638 F g−1) was also calculated to be higher than that of the CNFs paper (317 F g−1) (Figure 22d). Figure 22e showed the dependence of specific capacitance on current densities from 1 to 5 A g−1. It could be found that with the increase of discharge current density, the specific capacitance decreases accordingly. The composite electrode also exhibited a good electrochemical stability because the specific capacitance remained above 90% of the original value after 1000 cycles (Figure 22f). Another example of CNFs/PANI composite nanofiber membrane with a needle-like PANI nanowire arrays on the surface of CNFs showed much higher electrochemical performance than that of pristine PANI nanomaterials, including a larger specific capacitance and a greater stability.[304] There are some other examples on the fabrication of CNFs/conducting polymer composite nanofibers with designed architectures and good electrochemical performances for SCs.[305–307] As mentioned above, the addition of CNTs or graphene into the CNFs could be beneficial for the increase of the specific surface area and electrical conductivity. Conducting polymers were also often deposited on the surface of CNFs/CNTs or CNFs/graphene nanofibers to further improve the electrochemical performances.[308–311] For example, PANI coated CNFs/CNT composite nanofibers have been prepared by in situ polymerization of aniline on the surface of hierarchical CNFs/CNT network. The resultant CNFs/CNT/PANI exhibited porous hierarchical nanofibrous network architecture, which provided short channels for fast electron transport and effective current collection. In addition, the ultrathin PANI layer ensured the full utilization of active pseudocapacitor material, enabling to achieve a large specific capacitance and high energy and power densities. The SC device based on CNFs/CNT/PANI electrode displayed a specific capacitance as high as 503 F g−1 at a current density of 0.3 A g−1 and an excellent cycling stability of only ≈8% capacitance loss after 1000 cycles. The SC also showed a high energy density of ≈70 W h kg−1 and power density of ≈15 kW kg−1.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Electrospun Metal–Metal Oxide Composite Nanofibers
sections.text:
As one of the most important class of pseudocapacitor electrode materials, metal oxides have been received considerable attention due to their high specific capacitances. However, the poor electrical conductivity of metal oxides is a major drawback for power capability. Therefore, it is an urgent task to fabricate metal oxides with enhanced electrical conductivity to achieve fast discharge/charge rates.[312–314] In addition to CNFs,

combination of metal oxides with highly conductive metal is another meaningful strategy to incease their electrical conductivity. It has been reported that Pt nanofibers can be prepared via electrospinning followed by a calcination process. These Pt nanofibers can serve as supports for electrodepositing hydrous RuO2 to form Pt/RuO2 composite nanofibers.[312] They exhibited a core–sheath architecture with a 5 nm thick for RuO2 layer. Owing to the superior electron transport pathways from highly conductive Pt core to the hydrous RuO2 layer, the Pt/ RuO2 composite nanofibers electrode delivered a high specific capacitance of ≈409 F g−1 at 10 mV s−1 (based on the mass of hydrous RuO2 layer). In addition, a high rate capability with a capacity retention of about 79.6% from 10 to 1000 mV s−1 has also been achieved, indicating the contribution of the metal hybridization. NiCo2O4/Au composite nanotubes can be prepared by electrospinning a solution containing the precursors of Ni(NO3)2, Co(NO3)2, HAuCl4, and the PVP, followed by a calcination process.[313] Figure 23a,b showed the morhology and structure of the prepared NiCo2O4/Au nanocomposites, which revealed a mesoporous nanotubular architecture. Figure 23c displayed the CV curves of NiCo2O4/Au composite nanotubes, pristine electrospun NiCo2O4 nanotubes and NiCo2O4/Au composite nanoparticles, respectively. A higher current density and CV curve area were clearly observed for NiCo2O4/Au composite nanotubes, demonstrating their electrochemical reactivity. In detail, the material showed a superior pseudocapacitance of 1390 F g−1 at a current density of 5 A g−1 in 2 m KOH solution (capacity of 309 mA h g−1), which was much higher than those of pristine electrospun NiCo2O4 nanotubes (1045 F g−1, capacity of 232 mA h g−1) and NiCo2O4/Au composite nanoparticles (706 F g−1, capacity of 157 mA h g−1) (Figure 23d). Furthermore, the rate capability and cycling stablility of the NiCo2O4/Au composite nanotubes were also superior compared to those of pristine electrospun NiCo2O4 nanotubes and NiCo2O4/Au composite nanoparticles (Figure 23e). This indicated that both the addition of Au nanoparticles and the unique mesoporous nanotubular architecture played a crucial role on the enhancement of the electrochemical properties. A HEC device has also been fabricated by employing NiCo2O4/Au composite nanotubes as cathode and AC film on Ni foam as anode. The HEC device

sections.heading: 3.5.3. Electrospun Metal Oxide–Metal Oxide (Hydroxide) Composite Nanofibers
sections.text:
Nanocomposites composed of two different transition metal oxides with rational designed architectures have been proposed as electrode materials for SCs. The introduction of one metal oxide into another one reduces the charge transfer resistance of the metal oxide, resulting in fast electron transport within it. Additionally, hierarchical architectures such as porous and core–shell nanostructures provide fast ion diffusion and decrease the mass transport resistance, thus enhancing the electrochemical performance of the electrodes. In the past few years, a variety of metal oxide nanocomposites with a core– shell and porous heterostructures have been reported.[315–317] Electrospinning affords a simple and versatile approach for the fabrication of metal oxide composite nanofibers.[318–330] Our group has shown that the introduction of V2O5 into Fe2O3 composite nanofibers can effectively enhance the electrochemical performance of electrospun Fe2O3 nanofibers.[318] The V2O5/ Fe2O3 composite nanofibers with an appropriate mass of V2O5 showed a hollow architecture and exhibited an enhanced specific capacitance of 183 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 (capacity of 20 mA h g−1) compared to that of pristine Fe2O3 nanofibers (101 F g−1, capacity of 11 mA h g−1). In addition, the composite nanofibers delivered good rate capability and cycling stablility. When the charge–discharge rate increased to 5 A g−1, more than 60% of the capacitance was retained. And about 81.5% of the initial capacitance remained after 200 cycles. An enhanced electrochemical performance has also been observed in electrospun MnOx/SnO2 composite nanofibers. The specific capacitance of the composite nanofibers was 472 F g−1, which was much higher than that of MnOx (166 F g−1).[319] Recently, rationally designed hierarchical core–sheath structured ZnCo2O4@NiCo2O4 nanowires have been prepared by electrospinning, calcination, and co-precipitation.[329] The architecture of the nanowires consisted of mesoporous ZnCo2O4 as cores and nanosheet-like NiCo2O4 as the sheath. The material exhibited a much higher electrochemical performance than the individual components. The specific capacitance of the ZnCo2O4@ NiCo2O4 nanowires electrode reached 1476 F g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1 (capacity of 205 mA h g−1), and remained to be 942 F g−1 at 20 A g−1 (capacity of 131 mA h g−1). Meanwhile, the electrode maintained 98.9% capacitance after 2000 cycles, indicating a superior electrochemical stability. A 3D core–sheath structured ZnO@Ni(OH)2 nanofibers have been prepared by electrospinning followed by a hydrothermal reaction (Figure 24a).[330] SEM image of the as-prepared electrospun ZnO nanofibers revealed their interconnected structure with a smooth surface and relatively uniform diameter of around 100 nm (Figure 24b). After the hydrothermal process, hierarchical core–sheath structured ZnO/Ni(OH)2 nanofibers with a larger diameter of about 1 μm were fabricated (Figure 24c). The core–sheath structured ZnO@Ni(OH)2 nanofibers exhibited ultrahigh specific capacitance of 2218 F g−1 at 2 mV s−1 (capacity of 277 mA h g−1), which was much higher than that of pristine ZnO nanofibers of 112 F g−1 (capacity of 14 mA h g−1) and

sections.heading: 3.5.4. Electrospun Metal Nitride–Metal Nitride Composite Nanofibers
sections.text:
Transition metal nitrides have been proven to be good candidates as electrode materials for SCs due to their high molar density, superior chemical resistance and low cost. We have shown that electrospun VN hollow nanotubes electrode showed a good electrochemical performance.[194] However, VN exhibits a poor electrical conductivity, limiting its specific capacitance. The introduction of other metal nitrides into electrospun VN nanomaterials is a good strategy for efficient electron and ion transport. Cui and co-workers demonstrated a coaxial electrospinning process combined with a calcination and an ammonia treatment to prepare mesoporous core–sheath TiN/VN composite nanofibers.[331] The SEM image clearly showed the core–shell structure of TiN/VN nanocomposites, with the outer diameter of nearly 660 nm and the inner diameter of ≈300 nm (Figure 25a). As TiN exhibited a better electronic conductivity, the as-prepared mesoporous core–sheath TiN/VN composite nanofibers delivered a high specific capacitance of 185 F g−1 at a scan rate of 20 mV s−1, which was investigated by the CV curves. By comparison, electrospun TiN and VN nanofibers only exhibited a specific capacitance of 109 F g−1 and 157 F g−1, respectively (Figure 25b,c). The mesoporous core–sheath TiN/ VN composite nanofibers also displayed a good electrochemical

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
In this review, we have summarized the progress in electrospun nanomaterial electrodes for SCs, covering the composition evolution from CNFs, metal oxides, conducting polymers to composite nanomaterial, and architecture evolution from solid nanofibers to porous, core–sheath, hollow, and hierarchical structured nanomaterials. The advantages of the electrospun nanomaterials for SC electrodes mainly include the following three aspects: 1) the 1D morphology and the possibility to fabricate complex architectures provide materials displaying large surface area and porosities, high electrical conductivities, short diffusion pathways of the electrolytes, thus increasing the electrochemical performance. 2) Electrospinning is a simple approach that permits to incorporate multiple active components into a single nanofiber. The optimization of the interface
between two or more components can lead to excellent electrochemical performance due to the synergistic effects. 3) Finally, electrospinning offers the possibility to fabricate binder-free and flexible SC devices, providing the opportunity for their integration in novel applications.
Despite the great progress that has been achieved, many opportunities and challenges remain for the design and preparation of electrospun nanomaterials, and their SC applications:
Architecture Design: The size, pore structure, and morphology of the electrospun nanofibers play a key role in tuning the electrochemical performance. The fabrication of electrospun nanomaterials with tunable sizes, porosities, and uniform morphologies is still a challenge. Additionally, ideal SC electrode materials should also facilitate the rapid diffusion of the electrolyte. Some novel nanostructures such as core–sheath, hollow, fiber-in-tube and tube-in-tube structures have been shown to be the preferred morphologies due to the easy electrolyte diffusion. Porous 3D mats are good candidate as electrode material for SC and lithium ion batteries because they afford short diffusion pathways of the electrolytes. 3D electrospun polymer

nanofibers aerogel can be prepared by electrospinning followed by freeze-shaping technique.[332,333] It is expected that 3D electrospun polymer nanofibers aerogel derived CNFs or metal oxide nanofibers aerogel with multilevel porous characteristics would show the ideal characteristics for SCs electrodes.
Composition Optimization: In the electrospun composite nanomaterial electrodes, the control of the interface between the different components is vital for exhibiting synergistic effects. For example, nanocomposite consisting of a shell component with a large electrochemical activity and a core with a high conductivity is a common strategy for benefiting of both desired properties. In addition, doping is another versatile strategy to improve the electrochemical performance of the electrodes for SCs. For example, N-doping of carbon materials improves the charge mobility in CNFs, leading to an enhancement of the specific capacitance. It is also anticipated that other dopants such as fluorine and phosphorous could also increase the specific pseudocapacitance of electrospun CNFs due to an effective charge transfer between electrodes and electrolytes. Especially, doping with fluorine can increase the polarization and the electrical conductivity of the CNFs, resulting in an enhanced electrochemical performance.
Flexible SCs: Electrospun polymer nanofibers containing metal active electrochemical components have great potential for construction of flexible SC electrodes, but generally exhibit limited specific capacitances.[334–337] We have shown that flexible CNFs and conducting polymers are good candidates for the construction of flexible SCs. However, it is still a challenge to fabricate flexible metal oxide nanofiber-based SCs due to their poor mechanical properties. It has been reported that yttrium
doped TiO2 nanofibers were generally continuous with high aspect ratios and few cracks on the fibers exhibiting a flexible behavior.[338] It is anticipated that flexible and free standing electrochemical active metal oxide such as MnO2, Co3O4, and NiO nanofibers membrane might be prepared by the doping with rare metals to inhibit the grain growth of these metal oxides.
Mass Production: There is no question about the importance for mass production of SC electrodes for commercialization. The key point to increase the production rate is to generate multiple jets during the electrospinning process, thus multiple nozzles are regarded as one of the most promising approaches to achieve this objective.[339] However, an unstable jet-motion usually takes place due to the interruption near charged jets, limiting the stability and uniformity of the asprepared nanofibers on the collectors. In addition, the nozzle is also easily blocked by the polymer solution. The appearance of needleless electrospinning avoids the aforementioned disadvantages of the multiple nozzle electrospinning. By using a cylinder to initiate jets, multiple jets can be generated without interruption, which is beneficial for the design and development of large scale electrospinning setups. An industrial electrospinning equipment (Nanospinder) has been introduced in the market for the large scale production of various kind of polymeric and ceramic nanofibers.[340] Such an industrial-scale equipment might allow for the practical and commercial application of electrospun nanofibers-based SCs.
In the past few decades, SCs have been widely used in consumer electronic products, main power sources, and alternating power sources.[341] In comparison to battery systems, SCs displayed the advantages of fast charge/discharge
Figure 25. a) SEM image of TiN-VN fibers. b) CV curves of TiN, VN, TiN-VN fibers cycled between −1.2 and −0.2 V at a sweep rate of 20 mV s−1. c) Specific capacitances of the electrodes with TiN, VN, TiN-VN fibers as a function of scan rates. d) Cycling performance of TiN-VN fibers at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. Reproduced with permission.[331] Copyright 2011, American Chemical Society.
R ev iew
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (39 of 43) 1601301wileyonlinelibrary.com
capability, excellent cycle-life and high safety, which enables them to be potentially used in electric vehicles. Currently, it is a promising direction to develop energy storage systems with the combination of batteries and SCs for hybrid electric vehicles in the transportation market with the assistance of the high power delivery of SCs. For real-world application of SCs, it is a challenge to further improve the energy and power density of SCs. It is anticipated that by optimizing the composition and architecture of the active electrospun nanomaterial electrodes, high-performance SCs can be fabricated for highly-demanding applications.
In conclusion, this review summirized the progress to date on the architecture design of electrospun nanomaterials and their applications in SC electrodes. Considering the challenges the field is facing for the fabrication of high-performance SCs and for their integration in practical applications, further development of synthesis approaches to control the architecture and on device optimization to improve the SCs performance needs to be pursued. We trust that with additional efforts, most of the above issues may be solved and SCs based on electrospun nanomaterials will find their way toward real applications in the near future.

metadata.abstractText: With the fast consumption of fossil fuels and increasing environmental issues, there is an urgent need for the development of efficient, sustainable and renewable energy sources from Electrospinning is the most facile and highly versatile approach to produce 1D polymeric, inorganic, and hybrid nanomaterials with a small diameter, controllable dimensions, and designed architectures. In particular, with large surface area, high porosity, low density, good directionality, and tunable composition, electrospun nanofibers and mats are regarded as ideal candidates for various kinds of electrochemical energy storage devices such as supercapacitors (SCs). In this review, the recent progress in electrospun electrode materials for SCs is presented, covering the architecture design and their electrochemical performance. After a brief introduction about SCs, the basic principles of the electrospinning technique are discussed. Following, attention is paid to the discussion of various electrospun nanofibers and mats including 1D carbons, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitrides, conducting polymers and composite nanomaterials with various types of architectures as electrodes for SCs. The relationship between the composition, architecture, and the electrochemical performance is discussed in detail. Finally, some challenges and perspectives of future research of the electrospun nanofibers and mats for high performance SCs are highlighted. It is anticipated that this review would provide the researchers some inspiration for constructing new types of energy storage devices.
